options.label: A
options.text: To provide direct control over muscle movements

options.label: B
options.text: To manage muscle contractions beyond direct control

options.label: C
options.text: It binds to the smoothened protein, blocking its signaling

options.label: D
options.text: It increases the production of hedgehog protein

options.text: He was praised by the Pythagoreans

options.label: D
options.text: He was drowned by the gods

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Are you a body with a mind or a mind with a body? - Maryam Alimardani

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea behind the rubber hand illusion experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: To demonstrate the power of suggestion on human behavior

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To test the limits of human pain tolerance

options.label: D
options.text: To study the effects of virtual reality on human perception

multiple-choice.question: According to Ren√© Descartes, what is the ultimate proof of our existence?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: How can the mind exist without a physical body?

options.label: C
options.text: How can the mind be separate from the physical body?

options.label: D
options.text: How can the mind be connected to the physical body?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: That the mind is an illusion created by the brain

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: That the mind is a product of brain activity

options.label: C
options.text: That the mind-body problem is unsolvable

options.text: That the mind is an illusion created by the brain

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: They create new maps and representations in the brain

options.label: C
options.text: They are irrelevant to our experience of self

options.label: D
options.text: They are only important for our physical survival

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: A

options.text: That the mind is a product of brain activity

options.text: That the mind-body problem is unsolvable

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

title: Should we get rid of standardized testing? - Arlo Kempf

multiple-choice.question: When were the first standardized tests administered in China?

options.label: B
options.text: To determine aptitude for various government posts

multiple-choice.question: What type of curve is often used to express standardized test results in relation to other test takers?

options.label: A
options.text: 30% of test takers scored above her

options.label: B
options.text: 70% of test takers scored above her

options.label: C
options.text: 30% of test takers scored below her

options.label: D
options.text: 70% of test takers scored below her

multiple-choice.question: What is the usefulness of a standardized test dependent on?

options.label: A
options.text: Only the job it is asked to do

options.label: C
options.text: Both the job it is asked to do and its design

options.label: D
options.text: Neither the job it is asked to do nor its design

multiple-choice.question: What may be a limitation of standardized tests in measuring student learning?

options.label: C
options.text: They may not account for test anxiety or reading challenges

multiple-choice.question: What skills may be difficult for standardized tests to measure?

options.label: D
options.text: Aptitude for government posts and farming skills

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between reliability and validity in standardized testing?

options.label: A
options.text: Reliability refers to the consistency of results, while validity refers to the accuracy of interpretations

options.label: B
options.text: Reliability refers to the accuracy of interpretations, while validity refers to the consistency of results

options.label: C
options.text: Reliability and validity are interchangeable terms

options.label: D
options.text: Reliability and validity are not important concepts in standardized testing

multiple-choice.question: Why may standardized tests have limited usefulness in making important decisions about individuals?

options.label: C
options.text: They usually can't tell us a lot about a single person

options.label: D
options.text: They are too easy to cheat on

multiple-choice.question: Who is ultimately responsible for ensuring the appropriate use and interpretation of standardized test results?

options.label: D
options.text: The users of the test results

title: How do executive orders work? - Christina Greer

multiple-choice.question: What type of document was Abraham Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation?
What is the typical process for passing laws in the United States?

options.label: A
options.text: The president proposes a bill, which is then voted on by Congress.

options.label: B
options.text: A member of Congress proposes a bill, which is then approved by the president.

options.label: C
options.text: A member of Congress proposes a bill, which is then revised and voted on by Congress before being sent to the president for signature.

options.label: D
options.text: The president issues an executive order, which is then enforced by the courts.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between an executive order and a law?

options.label: A
options.text: An executive order is passed by Congress, while a law is issued by the president.

options.label: B
options.text: An executive order is enforced by the courts, while a law is not.

options.label: C
options.text: An executive order is issued by the president without consultation or permission from Congress, while a law is passed by Congress and signed by the president.

options.label: D
options.text: An executive order is permanent, while a law can be repealed.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of judicial review in relation to executive orders?

options.label: A
options.text: To ensure that executive orders are enforced by the courts

options.label: B
options.text: To determine whether executive orders are within the limits of the Constitution

options.label: C
options.text: To allow Congress to pass laws to counteract executive orders

options.label: D
options.text: To give the president unlimited power to issue executive orders

multiple-choice.question: What can a president's successor do to an executive order issued by the previous president?

options.label: A
options.text: They can amend it, but not repeal it.

options.label: B
options.text: They can repeal it, but only with the approval of Congress.

options.label: D
options.text: They cannot make any changes to it.

multiple-choice.question: When might a president use an executive order?

options.label: A
options.text: Only in times of crisis or emergency

options.label: B
options.text: Only when Congress is in session

options.label: C
options.text: To exert power without working with Congress, or to clarify and implement a policy

options.label: D
options.text: Never, as executive orders are unconstitutional

multiple-choice.question: What was the purpose of FDR's executive order establishing the Works Progress Administration?

options.label: B
options.text: To establish requirements for nondiscriminatory practices in hiring and employment

options.label: C
options.text: To build roads, bridges, and parks, and to employ artists and writers

options.label: D
options.text: To intern Japanese-Americans during World War II

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of an executive order being used to exclude and divide?

options.label: A
options.text: FDR's executive order establishing the Works Progress Administration

options.label: B
options.text: Harry Truman's executive order desegregating the armed forces

options.label: C
options.text: Lyndon Johnson's executive order establishing requirements for nondiscriminatory practices in hiring and employment

options.label: D
options.text: FDR's executive order interning Japanese-Americans during World War II

multiple-choice.question: How many executive orders did FDR issue during his presidency?
What can Congress do to counteract an executive order?

options.label: A
options.text: They can pass a law to repeal it

options.label: B
options.text: They can issue their own executive order

options.label: C
options.text: They can take the president to court

options.label: D
options.text: They can do nothing, as executive orders are absolute

multiple-choice.question: What event did scientists witness on September 14, 2015, that no human had ever seen before?

options.label: D
options.text: A comet passing close to Earth

options.label: B
options.text: A curve in a surface called space-time

options.label: C
options.text: A wave that travels through space

options.label: D
options.text: A particle that interacts with matter

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: By measuring changes in the Earth's magnetic field

options.label: C
options.text: Information about the Sun's energy output

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the sound produced by the collision of two black holes?

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The passing of a comet close to Earth

multiple-choice.question: What has LIGO revealed about black holes?

options.label: A
options.text: They are much smaller than previously thought

options.label: B
options.text: They are much more massive than previously thought

options.label: C
options.text: They collide more often than previously expected

options.label: D
options.text: They are only found in distant galaxies

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential impact of LIGO's discoveries on our understanding of the universe?

options.label: B
options.text: It will lead to a greater understanding of the Earth's atmosphere

options.label: C
options.text: It may revolutionize our understanding of the universe

options.label: D
options.text: It will have no significant impact

options.label: B

options.text: A cruel and savage serpent-like winged evil

multiple-choice.question: Who helped Psyche by gently lifting her into the air and setting her down before a palace?
What was the one question Psyche's husband told her she could never ask him?

options.label: D
options.text: The light of the full moon

options.label: B

options.label: A

title: The left brain vs. right brain myth - Elizabeth Waters

multiple-choice.question: What is the commonly-held myth about the human brain that is unsupported by scientific evidence?

options.label: A
options.text: The brain has a right and left side.

options.label: B
options.text: The left side controls movement and the right side controls sight.

options.label: C
options.text: The left side controls logic and the right side controls creativity.

options.label: D
options.text: The brain uses both sides to make a complete image of the world.

multiple-choice.question: What is the actual function of the left and right sides of the brain in terms of movement control?

options.label: A
options.text: The left side controls the motion of the left arm and leg.

options.label: B
options.text: The right side controls the motion of the right arm and leg.

options.label: C
options.text: The left side controls the motion of the right arm and leg.

options.label: D
options.text: The right side controls the motion of the left arm and leg.

multiple-choice.question: How does the brain process visual information from each eye?

options.label: A
options.text: Each eye sends information to the same side of the brain.

options.label: B
options.text: Each eye sends information to the opposite side of the brain.

options.label: C
options.text: Both left visual fields are sent to the left side of the brain.

options.label: D
options.text: Both left visual fields are sent to the right side of the brain.

multiple-choice.question: What is one theory for why the brain has a left-right structure for certain functions?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows for more complex nervous systems.

options.label: B
options.text: It gives a survival advantage of quicker reflexes.

options.label: C
options.text: It allows for more creative problem-solving.

options.label: D
options.text: It allows for more logical thinking.

multiple-choice.question: Who are the two neurologists that examined patients with communication problems due to injuries and suggested that language is controlled by the left side of the brain?

options.label: C
options.text: Robert Louis Stevenson and Charles Darwin

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of examining patients who were missing a hemisphere or had their two hemispheres separated?

options.label: C
options.text: They showed a complete range of behaviors, both logical and creative.

options.label: D
options.text: They showed no behaviors at all.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between language and attention in terms of brain function?

options.label: A
options.text: Language is more localized to the right side and attention to the left.

options.label: B
options.text: Language is more localized to the left side and attention to the right.

options.label: C
options.text: Language and attention are equally distributed between both sides.

options.label: D
options.text: Language and attention are not related to brain function.

multiple-choice.question: What is the conclusion about the idea of a left-right split between logic and creativity?

options.label: A
options.text: It is supported by scientific evidence.

options.label: B
options.text: It is not supported by scientific evidence, but it is still a useful concept.

options.label: C
options.text: It is not supported by scientific evidence, and it is not a useful concept.

options.label: D
options.text: It is still a topic of debate among scientists.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between logic and creativity in problem-solving and art?

options.label: A
options.text: Logic and creativity are mutually exclusive.

options.label: B
options.text: Logic and creativity are separate but equal.

options.label: C
options.text: Logic and creativity are intertwined and necessary for each other.

options.label: D
options.text: Logic and creativity are only necessary for certain tasks.

multiple-choice.question: What is the overall conclusion about brain function and behavior?

options.label: A
options.text: The brain functions as two separate hemispheres.

options.label: B
options.text: The brain functions as one unified whole.

options.label: C
options.text: The brain functions as a combination of both separate hemispheres and a unified whole.

options.label: D
options.text: The brain function is still not fully understood.

title: How does caffeine keep us awake? - Hanan Qasim

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated annual global consumption of caffeine?

options.label: B
options.text: To provide nutrients to the plant

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: How does caffeine keep humans awake?

options.label: A
options.text: By increasing the production of adenosine

options.label: B

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of adenosine in the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: To stimulate the central nervous system

multiple-choice.question: How does caffeine affect dopamine receptors?

options.label: C
options.text: It allows dopamine to bind to its receptors

options.label: D
options.text: It reduces the production of dopamine

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential long-term benefit of caffeine consumption?

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the body when it adapts to regular caffeine consumption?

options.label: A
options.text: It reduces the number of adenosine receptors

options.label: B
options.text: It increases the number of adenosine receptors

options.label: C
options.text: It reduces the production of adenosine

options.label: D
options.text: It increases the production of dopamine

multiple-choice.question: What is a symptom of caffeine withdrawal?
How long does it take for the body to readjust to not having caffeine after regular consumption?

title: How to spot a misleading graph - Lea Gaslowitz

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the most common ways graphs misrepresent data?

options.label: A
options.text: By using too many data points

multiple-choice.question: What type of graph is especially misleading when the scale is distorted?
What technique involves carefully choosing a time range to exclude the impact of a major event?

options.label: A
options.text: Because population growth always leads to an increase in data values

options.label: B
options.text: Because population growth can affect the interpretation of data trends

options.label: C
options.text: Because population growth is always a linear process

options.text: Because population growth is never relevant to data analysis

options.text: A slight increase in ocean levels

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to look at the context of a graph?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Because context can provide additional information about the data

options.label: D
options.text: Because context can change the interpretation of the data

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the organization that provided the ocean temperature data used in the example?
What type of graph is used to show the average temperature variation each year?
What is the main message of the transcript regarding graphs?

options.label: A
options.text: Graphs are always a reliable source of information

options.label: B
options.text: Graphs can be misleading if not interpreted carefully

options.label: C
options.text: Graphs are only useful for showing trends over time

options.label: D
options.text: Graphs are only useful for comparing categorical data

options.text: Just look at the lines and curves

options.label: B
options.text: Look at the labels, numbers, scale, and context, and ask what story the picture is trying to tell

options.label: C
options.text: Ignore the graph and look for other sources of information

options.label: D
options.text: Assume the graph is accurate and reliable
